name: Rumali Roti
history: Rumali Roti, which translates to 'handkerchief bread', is a thin, soft flatbread from Indian cuisine. Its name comes from its large size and thin, soft texture, resembling a handkerchief. It's a popular accompaniment in North Indian meals.
description: Rumali Roti is known for its extremely thin and soft texture. It's made from a dough of wheat flour and all-purpose flour, and is traditionally cooked on an inverted wok, giving it a unique texture that's soft yet slightly crispy.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine both types of flour, salt, and baking powder. Gradually add milk or water to form a soft dough. Knead well, adding a little oil or ghee. Let it rest for 20 minutes.

instructions.title: Roll Out the Roti
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Using a rolling pin, roll out each ball as thinly as possible, almost translucent.

instructions.title: Cook the Roti
instructions.description: Heat an inverted wok or large skillet. Place the rolled roti on it and cook for a few seconds until it puffs up. Flip and cook the other side briefly.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Fold the Rumali Roti like a handkerchief and serve hot with curries or kebabs.

nutrition.calories: 80 per serving (varies based on size and oil used)

tips: The key to perfect Rumali Roti is rolling the dough as thin as possible.
Cooking quickly on high heat ensures the roti remains soft.
variations: Add herbs or spices to the dough for additional flavor.
Try using different flour blends for a variation in texture.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh. Can be stored for a day when wrapped properly.
storage.instructions: Store in a cloth-lined container to retain softness.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a skillet or in a microwave until warm.
presentationTips: Serve in a basket or traditional Indian copperware for an authentic look.
Accompany with a variety of dips and curries for a complete meal.
